[Task Description]
You will be given DIALOGUE CONTEXT and MEMORY.
Your job is to judge if MEMORY contains helpful past information for a language model, representing Unknown, to generate a proper next response based on DIALOGUE CONTEXT.

If the DIALOUGE CONTEXT does not require the model to utilize past information for response generation, say "N/A".
Say "Yes" if MEMORY contains such helpful information and say "No" if it dose not.
Provide a brief explanation for your judgement.

[Format Regulation]
Generate your output below OUTPUT using the following format:
Brief explanation: your explanation
Judgement: "Yes", "No", or "N/A"

[Task]
DIALOGUE CONTEXT:
The garlic chicken sounds delicious. Can you make it? What kinds of spicy foods have you taught yourself to make?
Yes, it's one of my favorites! It always remind me of the good old days. Spicy foods are great for the kick they have...like spicy fried rice! You should come over and try it.
I would love to, I enjoy cooking so maybe you can teach me to make it, too?

[MEMORY]
Related Evidences: (1) {'Related Topics': 'Sharing Recipes', 'Related Summaries': 'Speaker B offers to share his grandmother's recipes with Speaker A, starting with the garlic chicken recipe.', 'Related Dialogues': '### Speaker A: Would you share any of your grandmother's recipes with me? ### Speaker B: Sure I would be happy to, which recipes would you like? ### Speaker A: Ever since you mentioned the garlic chicken I've been thinking about it.  I would love to have that recipe. ### Speaker B: Great I'll send that one over as well as a few others.  How is the surfing?' }(2) {'Related Topics': 'Grandma's Cooking and Family Dinners', 'Related Summaries': 'Speaker B reminisces about his grandmother's cooking, especially the garlic chicken, and family dinners with many relatives.', 'Related Dialogues': '### Speaker B: Haha, that's not a bad idea, but she didn't teach me many spicy recipes. I think my grandpa used to get indigestion when they first got together so she toned it down. I learned a couple on my own though. ### Speaker A: Well, I just know they are always so fantastic. What was it like growing up?  Did she always fix huge meals when you visited? ### Speaker B: Yep. She was definitely the matriarch and kept us together with family dinners. Whenever we'd go over, it would be about 12 of us, with my parents, uncles and aunts, and two of my cousins. We'd pitch in in different ways but grandma was the boss. Come to think of it, I'm not sure I ever visited her and not smelled something in the kitchen as soon as we got in. That garlic chicken especially was a staple.' }
